Globals
Global environment containing built-in constants, libraries, objects, and functions available in Traintastics Lua.

Examples
Control output on world run/stop

This examples monitors the world state and controls an output based on the `RUN` flag. If the world is in `RUN` state the output is off, if the world is stopped the output is on, e.g. for controller a red lamp.
Direction control using an input
This example show how to use an input to control a direction control board element on the board. This can e.g. be used for physical control panels that control board elements.

Zone

A zone groups multiple blocks into a logical area, such as a station, yard, or staging area. Zones make it easier to script behaviors that depend on a train’s location within a larger area, rather than tracking individual blocks.
The configured name of the zone.

Zone events fall into two categories:

- **Assignment events**: `on_train_assigned` and `on_train_removed` are triggered when a train is manually linked to or unlinked from a block in the zone. These indicate identification changes made by the operator, not movement.

- **Movement events**: `on_train_entering`, `on_train_entered`, `on_train_leaving`, and `on_train_left` are triggered as a train moves through the zone. They represent the lifecycle of a train entering, being inside, leaving, and fully leaving the zone.

Fired when a train starts moving into the zone by reserving or occupying its first block. This marks the point where the train begins to interact with the zone but is not yet fully inside it (see `on_train_entered`).

Unlike `on_train_assigned`, which is triggered when a train is manually linked to a block (e.g., placed on the track and assigned by the operator), `on_train_entering` reflects actual movement or reservation during operation.
the {ref:object.train|train} that is entering the zone.
the {ref:object.zone|zone} firing the event.

Fired when a train is manually assigned to the first block of the zone. This happens after a train has been placed on the track and the operator links it to the block, allowing Traintastic to recognize which train it is.

This event is about train identification, not movement.
the {ref:object.train|train} that is assigned to a block in the zone.
the {ref:object.zone|zone} firing the event.

Fired when a train starts to leave the zone by reserving or occupying a block that is not part of the zone. At this point the train still has blocks in the zone, but it is extending beyond its boundaries.
the {ref:object.train|train} that is leaving the zone.
the {ref:object.zone|zone} firing the event.

Fired when a train is fully inside the zone. A train is considered 'in the zone' only if it exclusively occupies blocks that belong to the zone.

!!! note
    If a zone is too small or the train too long, it may happen that while entering, the train simultaneously starts leaving the zone. In this case, the train is never fully inside, and `on_train_entered` will not be fired (only `on_train_entering` and `on_train_leaving` apply).
the {ref:object.train|train} that is in the zone.
the {ref:object.zone|zone} firing the event.
Fired when a train is no longer in the zone, a train is no longer in the zone when it doesn't occupy any block that are part of the zone.
the {ref:object.train|train} that has left the zone.
the {ref:object.zone|zone} firing the event.

Fired when a train is manually removed from the last block of the zone. This is the opposite of `on_train_assigned` and indicates the train is no longer linked to the zone.

This event is about train identification, not movement.
the {ref:object.train|train} that is removed from the zone.
the {ref:object.zone|zone} firing the event.

The {ref:pv|persistent variable} table.
Persistent variables

Persistent variables allow you to store data that survives script restarts and world save/load. They are useful for keeping state between sessions, such as counters, configuration values, or custom train data.

The {ref:globals#pv|`pv`} global provides a simple and efficient interface for interacting with persistent data. Any values stored in {ref:globals#pv|`pv`} are saved across script executions and world save and loads. Below is a detailed breakdown of how to use the {ref:globals#pv|`pv`} global.
Storing persistent data
You can store data in {ref:globals#pv|`pv`} just like you would with a regular Lua table.
Persistent variables supports storing booleans, numbers, strings, tables, {ref:enum|enums}, {ref:set|sets}, {ref:object|objects} and object methods.
Retrieving persistent data
To retrieve a previously stored value, including tables, access the corresponding key in the {ref:globals#pv|`pv`} global:
Deleting persistent data
To delete a stored persistent value, including tables, simply assign `nil` to the desired key:
Checking if data exists
To determine if a persistent variable has been set, use a `nil` checks. This pattern is useful for initializing default values or handling cases where the persistent variables are cleared.

Enum value represeting the state of a {ref:object.train|train} related to a {ref:object.zone|zone}. For long trains and/or short zones it is possible that a train is `LEAVING` before it fully `ENTERED` the zone, in that case `LEAVING` takes preference over `ENTERING`.
The {ref:object.train|train} is in the {ref:object.zone|zone}, it does not occupy any {ref:object.blockrailtile|block} outside the zone.
The front of the {ref:object.train|train} is in or has reserved at least one {ref:object.blockrailtile|block} of the {ref:object.zone|zone}.
The front of the {ref:object.train|train} is in or has reserved at least one {ref:object.blockrailtile|block} that is not of the {ref:object.zone|zone}.
The state is unknown, this value isn't used, it can be used for initialization purposes.
Object represeting the state of a train related to a zone.
If `true`, mutes all trains in the zone.
If `true`, disables smoke generators of all trains in the zone.s
List of {ref:object.trainzonestatus|train zone status} objects of all zones that the train is entering, has entered and/or is leaving.
Script throttle

Represents a script-accessible throttle object that can control a {ref:object.train|train} when acquired.
Throttle objects can be created using the `class.create_throttle()` function.
The name assigned to this throttle.
the {ref:object.train|train} currently controlled by this throttle, if any.
Attempts to acquire control of {ref:object.train|train} for this throttle.
The {ref:object.train|train} to acquire.
Optional flag allowing the throttle to steal control from another throttle, default is `false`.
Returns `true` if the {ref:object.train|train} was successfully acquired, `false` otherwise.
Reverses the current direction of the {ref:object.train|train} controlled by this throttle. The train can only change direcition if stopped.
Returns `true` if the direction was changed successfully, `false` otherwise.
Immediately stops the {ref:object.train|train} controlled by this throttle, bypassing any deceleration logic.
Returns `true`, only returns `false` if throttle is not acquired.
Releases control of the currently controlled {ref:object.train|train}.
Optional boolean indicating whether the {ref:object.train|train} should stop when released, default is `true`.
Sets the direction of the {ref:object.train|train}. The train can only change direcition if stopped.
The desired {ref:enum.direction|direction} for the {ref:object.train|train} (`enum.direction.FORWARD` or `enum.direction.REVERSE`).
Returns true if the direction was successfully set.
Sets the current speed of the {ref:object.train|train} directly.
The train speed in *unit*.
The {ref:enum.speed_unit|speed unit} (e.g. `enum.speed_unit.KMPH` or `enum.speed_unit.MPH`).
Returns `true` if the speed was successfully set, `false` otherwise.
Sets the target speed for the {ref:object.train|train}, allowing gradual acceleration or deceleration.
The desired target speed for the train in *unit*.
The {ref:enum.speed_unit|speed unit} (e.g. `enum.speed_unit.KMPH` or `enum.speed_unit.MPH`).
Returns `true` if the target speed was successfully applied, `false` otherwise.
Event triggered when the throttle successfully acquires a {ref:object.train|train}.
the throttle that is acquired control of the {ref:object.train|train}.
the {ref:object.train|train} that is acquired by the throttle.
Event triggered when the throttle releases control of its {ref:object.train|train}.
the throttle that released control.
Represents a block in the train control system. A block is a section of track that can detect, reserve, and track trains.
The name assigned to the block, used for the user interface.
The current state of the block, a {ref:enum.block_state|block state} value. Indicates whether the block is free, reserved, occupied, or its state is unknown.
List of {ref:object.trainblockstatus|train block status} objects with information about the trains in this block.

Fired when a train is manually assigned to the block. This happens after a train has been placed on the track and the operator links it to the block, allowing Traintastic to recognize which train it is.

This event is about train identification, not movement.

Fired when a train is manually removed from the block. This is the opposite of `on_train_assigned` and indicates the train is no longer linked to the block.

This event is about train identification, not movement.
Block state
Represents the current occupancy or reservation state of a {ref:object.blockrailtile|block} in the train control system.
Indicates that the block is free and not occupied or reserved by any train.
Indicates that the block is currently occupied by a train.
Indicates that the block has been reserved by a train but is not yet occupied.
Indicates that the block's state is unknown, typically due to missing or invalid data from feedback sensors.
Train block status

Represents the status of a {ref:object.train|train} in relation to a specific {ref:object.blockrailtile|block}. It provides information about which block the train occupies or interacts with, along with its direction and reference to the train.
The {ref:object.blockrailtile|block} associated with this status entry.
The direction of the train relative to the block, represented by a {ref:enum.block_train_direction|block train direction} value.
The {ref:object.train|train} this status entry refers to.
Color
Represents a set of standard named colors that can be used for display, signaling, or visualization within the train control system or user interface.
A bright cyan-blue color, often used for highlighting or informational indicators.
Black color, typically used for text, outlines, or inactive elements.
Blue color, commonly used to represent normal operation, information, or neutral states.
A vivid pink-purple color, often used for emphasis or alerts.
Gray color, usually used for disabled or inactive elements.
Green color, typically representing safety, readiness, or 'go' states.
Bright lime-green color, a lighter variant of green often used for visibility or highlights.
Dark red color, sometimes used to indicate caution or reserved conditions.
Dark blue color, typically used for professional or subdued indicators.
Represents the absence of a color or transparent state.
Olive green color, often used for muted or intermediate visual states.
Purple color, commonly used for secondary or auxiliary indicators.
Red color, typically representing danger, stop, or error conditions.
Light gray or silver color, used for neutral or decorative purposes.
Teal color, a blue-green hue used for calm or neutral indicators.
White color, representing neutrality, clarity, or background elements.
Yellow color, typically used for warnings, attention, or intermediate states.
Input channel

Defines the input channel type used by supported hardware interfaces to receive sensor or feedback data. By default, the channel is `INPUT`, but other channels are used for specific systems such as Z21, ESU ECoS, or LDI HSI-88.
Input channel used by the {ref:object.ecosinterface} for ESU ECoS Detector feedback modules.
Default input channel type used for general-purpose inputs not tied to a specific hardware interface.
Input channel used by the {ref:object.z21interface} for LocoNet-based feedback modules.
Input channel used by the {ref:object.z21interface} for RBus-based feedback modules.
Input channel used by the {ref:object.ecosinterface} for S88 feedback modules.
Input channel for the left S88 bus segment on the {ref:object.hsi88interface}.
Input channel for the middle S88 bus segment on the {ref:object.hsi88interface}.
Input channel for the right S88 bus segment on the {ref:object.hsi88interface}.
Output pair value

Defines the active output within a pair used by accessory-type outputs such as turnouts or signals. Each pair has two lines, where only one is active at a time — typically referred to as red/green or thrown/closed.
Indicates that the first output in the pair is active. This is commonly referred to as the red or thrown state.
Indicates that the second output in the pair is active. This is commonly referred to as the green or closed state.
Indicates that the active output in the pair is undefined, meaning neither output is currently active or the state cannot be determined.
Speed unit
Specifies the unit of measurement used for train speed values.
Speed expressed in kilometers per hour (km/h). Commonly used in metric-based regions.
Speed expressed in miles per hour (mph). Commonly used in imperial-based regions.
Speed expressed in meters per second (m/s).
Text alignment
Defines how text is positioned within a display or layout area, combining vertical and horizontal alignment options.
Text is aligned to the bottom and horizontally centered.
Text is aligned to the bottom and flush to the left.
Text is aligned to the bottom and flush to the right.
Text is centered both horizontally and vertically.
Text is vertically centered and aligned to the left.
Text is vertically centered and aligned to the right.
Text is aligned to the top and horizontally centered.
Text is aligned to the top and flush to the left.
Text is aligned to the top and flush to the right.
Communication protocol used by a digital decoder to receive commands from the command station.
Sensor state
Defines the possible states of a track sensor. Depending on the set type sensors report section occupancy (free/occupied), or event triggers (idle/triggered).
Section-based state indicating that no train is present in the monitored track section.
Position-based state indicating that the sensor is inactive and waiting to be triggered  (e.g., reed switch, IR sensor, or hall sensor).
Section-based state indicating that a train occupies the monitored track section.
Position-based state indicating that the sensor has been activated by a passing train.
Indicates that the current sensor state cannot be determined, possibly due to communication issues or an uninitialized input.
Represents the visual aspect or indication shown by a railway signal, defining how a train should proceed based on track conditions ahead.
Indicates that the train may proceed at the permitted line speed. Typically shown as a green aspect.
Indicates that the train may proceed but must reduce speed, often due to an upcoming occupied block or diverging route. Typically shown as a yellow aspect.
Indicates that the train must stop before the signal. Typically shown as a red aspect.
Indicates that the signal aspect is not known or cannot be determined, possibly due to configuration or communication issues.
Output channel

Defines the communication channel or protocol used for controlling digital outputs such as accessories, turnouts, and signals. The available options depend on the connected command station or hardware interface.
Generic accessory channel used when the interface supports only one protocol for accessory control.
Accessory channel using the DCC protocol, available on systems that support multiple protocols to control accessories.
Accessory channel using the Motorola protocol, available on systems that support multiple protocols to control accessories.
DCCext channel as defined in the RCN-213 standard, used for extended DCC accessory communication.
ECoS object channel representing a turnout or signal defined in an ESU ECoS command station.
Output channel specific to the {ref:object.dccexinterface}, used for controlling general-purpose outputs.
Turnout channel specific to the {ref:object.dccexinterface}, used for controlling turnout (switch) outputs.
Defines how an output behaves or is structured, depending on the selected output channel or the type of accessory being controlled.
Used for multi-aspect signals where the output represents a specific signal aspect, such as red, yellow, or green. Typically applies to DCCext (RCN-213).
Represents an ESU ECoS object state, such as a turnout or signal defined within the ECoS command station.
Generally used for accessory outputs that form a logical pair, where one output is active at a time (e.g., red/green or thrown/closed).
Used for a single, independent output, typically representing an on/off function such as a light or relay control.
